Abstract: This study explores the intricate relationship between water insecurity and human biology, focusing on the physiological and psychological impacts of inadequate water access. Through a comprehensive review of existing literature, the research highlights how chronic water insecurity can lead to persistent dehydration, affecting cognitive function, physical performance, and overall health. The study also examines the embodiment of water scarcity, revealing how the experience of thirst and the constant need to secure water influence human behavior and coping strategies. Additionally, the research underscores the exacerbating role of climate change in water scarcity, which disproportionately affects vulnerable populations. By integrating insights from human biology, environmental science, and social studies, this paper provides a holistic understanding of the multifaceted impacts of water insecurity on human health and well-being.
